resources.string: You can choose any of the availiable BAT languages, not all of them are included in this app but if you need them, we can add them.

Click on this link to download our most recent publication (in French) which discusses the Android BAT project, its data collection in a clinical or research context as well as how you can use this app, or adapt it (and/or it\'s codebase) to make your own experiments or patient training materials for Android smart phones or touch tablets.

The AndroidBAT gives \'eyes,\' \'ears,\' and \'skin,\' to the BAT stimuli books. It\'s Androidification was supported by iLanguage Lab ltd, an OpenSource Fieldlinguistics company in Montreal, Canada. The Android BAT project began in February 2011 when Gina and Alexandra decided combine their expertise to make it easier to run experiments/collect language data in real world contexts. \n Programming: Gina Cook & Kim Dan Nguyen; User Guide: Émie Dessureault & Alexandra Marquis; Logo: Émie Dessureault & Alexandra Marquis
You must download the evaluator\'s PDF from the McGill BAT site which provides the instructions on how to administer the Bilingual Aphasia Test. Click this link to download the PDFs on this tablet.

Special thanks to Dr. Paradis and the Bilingual Aphasia Test community, our Speech Language Pathology interns Émie and Kim, the Montreal Computational Linguistics community, the Montreal Linguistics community, Android Montreal, Javascript Montreal and all the Open Source developers whose code, comments and feedback which directly or indirectly contributed to making this project possible!

The BAT design and stimuli are copyright their original authors. The code which powers this app is using OPrime: Open Experimentation for Android which is released under the Apache 2.0 License. Free to modify the code to your needs! Click here to see the code.
